awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of The Texas Women in Mathematics Symposium (TWIMS) which will be held on February 1-2 2020 at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas. The aim of TWIMS is to highlight the research of women mathematicians in Texas, to strengthen the network of Texas-based women mathematicians, to provide a supportive platform for women mathematicians to present their work. This is the fourth TWIMS conference, following events held at the University of Texas at Austin, Sam Houston State University, and the University of Houston. 

The primary aims of TWIMS at Texas A&M University are: to showcase the research of women mathematicians in Texas; to strengthen the network of Texas-based women mathematicians; to provide a supportive platform for women mathematicians to present their work; to explore issues surrounding being a woman in mathematics; to find collaborators and mentors and begin long-lasting professional relationships. Conference details can be found at http://awm.math.tamu.edu/twims2020.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The 4th annual Texas Women In Mathematics Symposium (TWIMS) was held on February 1-2, 2020. Nearly 100 mathematicians from across all regions of Texas visited the Texas A&M University campus for the two-day conference aimed at strengthening the network of women, gender minorities, and allies working in mathematics while also encouraging the growth of related collaborations and relationships throughout the Lone Star State. The main conference goals were to 

-Learn about the research of women in Texas

-Present research in a supportive environment

-Network with Texas women mathematicians, and

-Explore issues surrounding being an underrepresented group in mathematics.


The event was organized by Priyanga Ganesan, Laura Matusevich, Nida Obatake, Aleksandra Sobieska-Snyder, and Elise Walker, and it was sponsored by the National Science Foundation, the Mathematical Association of America, the Texas A&M Department of Mathematics and the Texas A&M College of Science.


In addition to two plenary speakers, University of Texas at Austin mathematician Dr. Irene M. Gamba and Texas Tech University mathematician Dr. Raegan Higgins, the event showcased six panelists: World Wide Technology?s Dr. Nicole Bridgland; the Air Force Research Laboratory?s Dr. Lauren Ferguson; Shell Canada Limited?s Dr. Dinara Khalmanova; St. Edward University?s Dr. Kaitlyn Phillipson; Indiana University?s Dr. Julia Plavnik; and the University of Chicago?s Dr. Fatma Terzioglu. Both days featured a plenary talk, breakout sessions, and networking. There were 15 contributed talks, which were presented in parallel sessions on Saturday. Sunday?s activities included a professional development panel and mock interviews.


The annual symposium provided participants with a unique opportunity to learn about the research of other female mathematicians in Texas while exploring a host of related issues from diverse perspectives. Conference participants noted the inclusive, welcoming atmosphere, and opportunities for networking. Participants were engaged with the scientific activities, and the professional development panel was most widely praised.


Last Modified: 12/22/2020
Modified by: Nida K Obatake
